tweets.text: 0/In response to the prompt from @vgr, the topic is responsibility.
1/Responsibility is fundamentally about ownership. Of your choices, commitments, contracts... and the side effects and implications that stem from them, unexpectedly and sometimes years later.
2/Crucially, these implications often cannot be known prior to the commitment being made. We try to control for rogue outcomes but it's like placing odds on a probability with a variable denominator.
3/It's not just that we can't know the future. It's also that the future can't know the past. We must Act, but we are given no assurances that posterity will not condemn us.
4/We are additionally constrained by our finitude. Even our most simple choices, such as what to eat, or wear, or entertain ourselves with, possess our attention for a time, and condition us.
5/Irresponsibility is a sort of breaking of trust with your past self. It manifests as a disregard for the connectedness of things.
6/No choice is beyond integration.
7/Irresponsibility leaves one susceptible to control. Propaganda is most effective when you do something... and are forced to come up with a motive or commitment that could have driven your action.
8/Reducing choices and commitments, simplifying contracts, allows for tremendous time and energy to be freed up.
9/When you start with an impossible goal in mind, and work backward, reality stretches to accommodate.
10/Good intentions are their own, and their only, reward. Better to be effective.
11/You are capable of pushing through far more suffering than you know, if you have a reason to.
Belatedly continuing after a brief illness detour.
12/Responsibilities are implicit claims made upon you; by yourself or by others.
13/Claims from others will generally stem from a group membership or an established relationship, but they can also be foisted upon you by the general public or random individuals.
14/How seriously you take these claims will generally relate to your own claims of responsibility you put upon yourself. These come from your own values, and who or what you stake your identity in.
15/A group that you identify strongly with can make significant claims upon you and you will accept them. Most religions work this way.

16/However, groups that you identify weakly with (or not at all) can equally make claims and, if their power is coercive enough, see you accept them, however begrudgingly. Many employee relations operate this way, as does our relationship to the law in some situations.
17/The same goes for individuals. When your partner asks that you take ownership of something, it's in the context of a highly entangled interdependency.
18/Or it could be that some guy you met on the internet (@vgr) throws the gauntlet and you opt in to pick up what he threw down.
19/The claim-makers may not exist at an equal scale, physically or temporally.

20/Cultural or ancestral traditions cast claims forward to the present. The fact that the claimants are not alive does diminish the fact that one is presented with a decision to continue or terminate the process in your own life.
21/Or creatively reinterpret, embracing the spirit over the letter of the claim (or the letter over the spirit).
22/The future, similarly, makes a claim to the extent that one cares about posterity and descendents (genetic or otherwise).
23/To "not choose" is in fact a choice, whether to ignore claims of the past or of the future.
24/In the present, we negotiate all these implicit and explicit claims, and make de facto prioritizations.
25/Mostly these can be boiled down to simple root concerns. What is revealing are the subtle deviations.
Getting pulled away by, ironically, other responsibilities. More when I'm able.
